body:
r? @huonw

(rust_highfive has picked a reviewer for you, use r? to override)
There are some `TODO` lines in there. Should these stay in there? Should they be replaced with special block markup that? Is there precedence for this in TRPL?
@killercup I don't think TARPL is supposed to be read yet, it's in-progress and @Gankro's just merging it to get more eyes on it, so we can leave the TODOs be :smile:

@Manishearth, too late, now I've read it! :smile:

These TODOs may be useful even after it is 'published', though. I was just wondering if there was a thing like `<aside class="todo">` to separate this from the actual text (a bit like Wikipedia). Or, we could just `<!-- TODO: Use HTML comments for TODOs -->` if they are only meant to be seen be the writer.

Huge :+1: . Read through the whole thing (sort of skipped things which I'd read when this was TURPL), and enjoyed it a lot. Learned a lot of new things, and had some laughs too :smiley_cat: . Might give this another go-through for more nits, but overall is totes awesomesauce omg.

Can't wait for this thing to be finished!
Many nits addressed.
Assigning to Steve for ultimate responsibility, but see list of requested reviews above

I'd like to consider the presentation carefully before merging another full book. Two questions:
- Could this reasonably be merged into the existing book?
- The name is sure to draw a lot of confusion, it is so similar to The Book. This used to be about 'unsafe', but now it's 'advanced' - what is the scope here, and can the name be less ambiguous?

> The name is sure to draw a lot of confusion, it is so similar to The Book. This used to be about 'unsafe', but now it's 'advanced' - what is the scope here, and can the name be less ambiguous?

This is following a discussion with Dave in #research --  the title "The unsafe Rust PL" has the undertone that "Rust is an unsafe language". The updated version of the book also contains more than just unsafe rust.

But yeah, a more distinguishable title would be nice.

> Could this reasonably be merged into the existing book?

So, I used to be of this opinion, but given that it's something that only matters to a small section of Rust's audience, and it's _also_ a huuuuuuuge topic, I like the idea of it being twins, rather than together. I'm not totally opposed to putting them together, I just think I lean towards them as compliments at the moment.

With 'advanced' rather than 'unsafe', this justification is much, much weaker.

Note that changing the title to "advanced" is largely a political one. The focus of the text is largely still around writing unsafe code and all the things you need to know to do it correctly. It is not inaccurate to refer to all those things as "advanced" rust, though.
What about "Writing safe unsafe code in Rust"? Or, less cute, "Writing correct unsafe code in Rust".
"How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the `unsafe`"
CC @dherman
I feel TRPL and TURPL should be in separate git repos, and that does not have to affect their official status (e.g. they should be part of rust-lang org).
@tshepang we've decided explicitly against that for now, so it's off-topic as far as this PR is concerned.
I figured out how to properly handle the "misc lifetimes" stuff. Properly sharded out, with dropck getting its own dedicated section.

src/doc/tarpl/exotic-sizes.md line 66 should be
normally does to store and retrieve values will be completely stripped in
@nrc comments addressed

@Gankro in reply to some comments which have disappeared:

> Can you give a concrete example?

We check that integers aren't cast to bool, we check that only unsized arrays are not cast to trait objects, only other arrays, etc.

> Can you give an example of where it applies but another doesn't? Coercions apply almost everywhere already.

Type inference. Satisfying where clauses.
@huonw I think I've addressed all your comments.

I've redone splitting lifetimes after discussing safely implementing IterMut with @arielb1 

http://cglab.ca/~abeinges/blah/turpl/_book/lifetime-splitting.html

I'm reverting the reviewed status of the ownership section as a significant portion has been reworked since it was reviewed.
this desperately needs squashing
@tshepang This isn't even closed to being accepted.

@Gankro 

I just re-read the ownership section. Comments below. We should also discuss in person -- I have a few thoughts about the overall structure, and some improvements to the key early sections.

General style point: the book is somewhat inconsistent in when it uses code formatting outside of snippets — e.g. Box is plain text but `*mut T` is quoted.

# 4.1 References

## References

Second set of bullets — formatting messed up

## Paths

“If all Rust had were values” — add “(no pointers)”

Might make more sense to say that you have a “forrest” of ownership, with each stack slot being the root of one tree. That’s closer to how I think of things personally. (That also lets you say that globals and thread-locals are just additional roots.)

Some concrete examples early on would be helpful in bringing these ideas across clearly.

“References to a value can subsequently be interpreted as a path in this tree.” -> I think it’s ultimately worth spelling this out in more detail — maybe we can discuss a bit in person exactly what you mean by this.

“establishing a unique path” — perhaps “a unique _live_ path”?

I’m not sure whether the initial distinction between stack and heap is actually worthwhile. For a long time people thought of `T` and `Box<T>` as radically different things, but for most purposes in Rust they are identical — a “mere” representation choice. Maybe a simpler framing would be to introduce the idea of trees and paths, and that things are simple as long as paths are unique — then show that they are unique for stack data, globals, and uniquely owned heap data. Again, slightly more detailed/concrete examples would be helpful here.

“Shared ownership means there is no unique path” -> “Shared ownership of a value means that there is no unique path to it”.

“A value with no unique path limits what we can do with it” -> helpful to tie this back to earlier examples of e.g. mutating a shared value causing trouble.

“The most common way to establish such a path is through interior mutability” — that’s not quite right, or at least, it’s not as clear as it could be. But I think it’s easiest to talk about that one in person, to figure out a more precise framing.

## Liveness

Here you switch to talking about references, but I think it’s actually clearer if you continue to talk about _paths_. For example, paths going through stack ownership (with no references involved) still undergo freezing, meaning that the following doesn’t compile:

``` rust
struct Point { x: i32, y: i32 }

fn main() {
    let mut p = Point { x: 1, y: 3 };
    let borrowed = &mut p;
    println!("{}", p.x);
}
```

So I think liveness/frozenness should be a property of paths in general, with references 

On that note, it’s worth pinging @nikomatsakis about the use of “reborrowing” here, versus “freezing”. That is, the existing terminology focused on “removing” liveness of existing paths by freezing them.

“To simplify things, we can model variables as a fake type of reference” - I think that if you reformulate this story as being about paths rather than references, this paragraph won’t be needed. Let’s discuss.

# 4.2 Lifetimes

“Our examples made use of aggressive sugar” - maybe add “Originally, our examples . . .”

## Example: references the outlive referents

Should say “Example 1” to match later section.

“the scope the scope”

# 4.5 Unbounded lifetimes

“he most common source of this is derefencing a raw pointer, which produces a reference with an unbounded lifetime.” - would be helpful to actually show the impl for Deref here.

Also helpful to say that “unbounded” means that there are no constraints on how big/small the lifetime must be. Point is that when these arise in practice, there _are_ actual constraints, but you need to tell Rust what they are.

This section still feels underdeveloped to me. I think it’s a lot more useful to explain this material in the context of an example of unsafe code.

# 4.6 HRTBs

“basically produces an inifinite list of trait bounds that F must satisfy” - worth saying that the only way to satisfy such a bound is through a blanket impl. 

# 4.7 Subtyping and variance

“This is the general theme of variance vs invariance: if variance would allow you to store a short-lived value over a longer-lived slot, then you must be invariant.” 

# 4.10 Splitting lifetimes

“so that it can be treated as disjoint from the other until we unify them when we return.” - this was a little terse. Helpful to break this out into some more explicit steps (making more clear how lifetime elision is playing out here, and how the lifetime ultimately is bounded)

“However it actually does work, exactly because iterators are one-shot objects.” - that, and because the iterator is tied to a mutable borrow of the original object that lives as long as the iterator (and the references it produces) does.

Not sure that DoubleEndedIterator is worth showing.

Also, the fact that the slice case works out is due to already “teaching” Rust about splitting mutable slices through `split_at_mut`.
(My comments about the Ownership section can be addressed in later iterations; I'm happy to r+ this for now.)

Comments on the ~~RAII~~ ORBM chapter:
- The section title should probably be "Ownership Based Resource Management" since that's the term you use internally. Also, I would love to kill the use of "RAII" in our docs in favor of OBRM or OORM or something along those lines.
- Intro is good.
- Constructors section is good.
- Destructors section:
  - Have you explained the full details of `Unique` at this point? You mention the dtor seeing it as an `*mut` pointer but it may not be so clear to the reader.
  - "Similarly nothing can use- after-free the ptr because the Box is immediately marked as uninitialized." I found this confusing -- I'm not sure what you're trying to emphasize here. In particular the fact that `drop` was running at all indicates that the box cannot be used directly any more -- so you might be more explicit about the scenario that's being protected against here.
- Leaking:
  - "Many people like to believe that Rust eliminates resource leaks, but this is absolutely not the case, no matter how you look at it." This is similar to the claim that Rust "eliminates races" -- absolutely false in any purely technical sense, but with a fair amount of truth in practice.
  - The description of the scoped API is a little incomplete for readers not already familiar with it. Could be helpful to discuss the basic idea of joining the thread via a guard first, before the code example. (Might also want to just paste in the basic signatures of the API).
  - "The thread::scoped API intends to allow threads to be spawned that reference data on the stack without any synchronization over that data" -- this isn't quite right. More simply, the intent is to allow sharing stack data between a parent thread and some children threads, by ensuring that the parent joins the children before popping that stack data.
  - Otherwise, this section is really great :+1: 

r+ on this section after above addressed

## Ownership comments

### 4.1 References

#### Paths

Are you talking about "ownership paths" or "lvalue paths"? Rust does not attempt to semantically track "ownership paths" - in fact, Rust can work with references to objects owned by FFI code, with no in-Rust ownership path (also, in the presence of types like `Rc`, ownership paths are unclear). An object graph is a cleaner model.

lvalue paths are the language concept tracked by `mem_categorization`. You can easily have zero (only accessible via a raw pointer), one (regular variable), or more (immutably borrowed) lvalue paths to a given object. lvalue roots are distinct from ownership roots (e.g. references are lvalue roots but not ownership roots in any interesting way).

Interior mutability allows you to create a mutable lvalue path/reference to the interior of an `UnsafeCell<T>` given a immutable lvalue path/reference to its exterior and a proof that the mutable path is unique - it does not do anything with ownership paths (the main effect of an `UnsafeCell` is to stop the immutable path from propagating to its interior, which would cause an instant aliasing violation when its interior is accessed).

Owning references/`&move` are kind-of a language concept that isn't completely reified.

#### Liveness

Might be worth noting that this is a distinct concept from GC-liveness.

#### Reborrowing

lvalues are frozen or borrowed, not reborrowed. A reborrow is just a dereference followed by a borrow. Disjoint lvalues may be simultaneously borrowed without causing aliasing violations, even if they have the same lvalue root (of course, this is only allowed by the borrow checker if _it_ can prove the lvalues disjoint, but this isn't UB in other cases if done by unsafe code).

#### Aliasing

Of course, aliasing is a matter of lvalue paths, not ownership paths. You can also have aliasing violations via FFI: if you modify, by writing, or any other way (`munmap`, `remap_file_pages`, DMA, etc.), memory accessible by a borrowed path.

@arielb1 Note that the references section is in no way trying to model how borrowck or the type checker works -- it's trying to capture the semantics that we actually care about in a correct program (in particular, all the nonsense unsafe code is allowed to do).

However the case of FFI is an interesting one -- I haven't thought about to handle cross-language semantics.
@Gankro I reviewed nearly everything up through the "Uninitialized Memory" chapter.  Not sure if I'll get to the rest any time soon, but I'm sure my comments on those parts can wait.

@Gankro 

Ownership paths are not a language concept. They are not relevant to safety (except as they help you avoid double-frees), not relevant to `Cell`, not relevant to anything. I don't think you have to explicitly talk about lvalue paths, just to use that concept instead of ownership paths.

References.md is now the only major outstanding issue.

Everything else I believe can be handled after landing this (omg I want to land this)

I'm tempted to just tear out references.md as temporary measure.
